narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a knowledge on several environmental justice issues that plague our nation right now.
Learned how to analyze text and apply it to environmental policy.
Improved writing skills. Learned about an important topic. Had an incredible time.

This class was one of the best I have ever taken, I highly recommend anyone interested in the environment, justice, or just wants to learn about some really interesting historical injustice cases take this class.

I learned the importance of brevity in writing and how to get my argument across in a concise way. I learned the basic principles that create the foundation for justice, the history of environmental writing, and how to put these two together. I enjoyed learning about resources at Yale in a way that specifically related to our course.

The course's main focus was to help us develop critical research skills for our academic careers later on. I believe I learned exactly that in our classes. I know which sources to consult to delve into a comparative analysis of the arguments of different authors interested in my topic. It is also important to mention that not all sources are reliable; oftentimes, in fact, unverified sources produce unreliable data. Professor Fotos taught us how to identify an authentic paper, statistical report, or case-based investigative journalism and effectively integrate them into our research endeavors, avoiding untrustworthy and biased sources.

Finding sources is the first big step in conducting successful research. The next challenging task is to assemble a comprehensive list of those sources, collected around the aim of the research. I learned a successful list supports the main argument made by the author of the paper while acknowledging other possible interpretations of the text, case, or event investigated. The Final Project of the course was to create a list of sources for annotated bibliography on my research topic. The assignment enabled me to apply the knowledge we gained in our seminars about synthesizing sources to have a meaningful research experience.
I learned so much from the guest speakers and the possibilities of Yales environmental studies program.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Some of the readings were long and unnecessary. I wish we did more  group discussions rather than having speakers come in and speak to us for long periods of time.

The class is well structured for content, but poorly structured for assignments. Professor Fotos does not provide any clear rubric for assignments and often it feels like your grade in the class is directly correlated with his own personal opinion towards you.
No recommendations. This was great.

It is an amazingly designed class that does well in covering fundamental definitions, writing instruction, and real life case studies. My only suggestion, which is incredibly minor, would be to have the guest speakers more evenly distributed through the semester if possible.

I think the guest speakers for the senior essays could have been spread out a bit more throughout the semester because I felt that we did not get to discuss much as a class by the end of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if they are interested in environmental justice issues.

I would recommend this course to another student because I was given the opportunity to read insightful papers and learn about currently environmental issues and engage with these topics in a productive seminar-based way.
I would not recommend this class unless you are planning to be an EVST major.
Absolutely! Loved the instructor and gained an interest in topic.
Yes, this is an insanely well taught class and Professor Fotos truly is an expert who is super passionate about the topics.
Yes, I would highly recommend this course to any first-year who wants an introduction to environmental justice and yale resources in general.

To anyone curious about defining justice in the context of environmental problems, I strongly suggest considering this course. From rediscovering what concise writing means to establishing a good understanding of literature review, Professor Fotos will guide students throughout the course with extensive feedback and generous assignments to ponder upon.
Good intro to the EVST major.
